custom-block.l: This category contains blocks from different mathematical fields. From linear algebra there are vectors and matrices that can be created in different ways. The properties of vectors, e.g. minimum, variance or standard deviation, can be determined directly. With scalars, vectors, and matrices all arithmetic operations can be performed. With the help of matrices, mappings are realized or systems of equations are solved. Complex numbers in Cartesian (cnC) or polar form (cnP) can also be calculated. Vectors and complex numbers as well as figures defined by vectors are displayed on a MathPad in two or three dimensions. The MathPad can also show numerical sets. From numerical mathematics come blocks for determining the roots of a function, series and series elements, and derivatives. Finite series and integrals are also calculated. For frequency analyses, a block for the Fast Fourier Transformation (FFT) as well as its inverse serves. In addition, the frequency spectrum can be output. For statistical purposes, blocks of the usual distribution functions are available. Sets can be defined by an enumeration of elements, intervals or predicates. After that, blocks are available for all set operations. If possible, sets are converted into interval lists. If this does not succeed, then the subset and the equality predicate are not determined in some cases. There are some more hidden blocks for dealing with sets, e.g. to merge interval lists, to determine their intersection, to turn predicates into intervals, and so on. You can find them in the list "export blocks" from the file menu.

block-definition.comment: This block deletes all the variables with the names given (inside input list). Each name will make only one variable deletion, and this will be the variable found following the scope order: 'script' -> 'sprite' -> 'global'. If we have a "testing" sprite variable and also a "testing" global one, deleting "testing" will delete only the sprite one (Yes! we can also do "delete var (testing, testing)" to delete both. If one variable does not exists (in any scope) an error happens, stopping block action in that point. You can check it before with the "does var (name) exists?"block.

Returns a set by listing the elements, predicates, and defined intervals. The three sections are treated as a disjunction: Elements belong to the set if they are enumerated, lie within intervals, or satisfy the predicate. If possible, they are defined by intervals. The sequence is: <set><isNumerical><list of elements><list of intervals><predicate>.

Creation of a set by one numerical interval. Predicates and elements should be defined by other blocks. Returns a set by listing the elements, predicates, and defined intervals. custom-block.l: This category contains blocks to deal with data, mainly organized as tables. Data can be imported from different sources, or can be created in different ways. If they are imported to the SciSnap!Data-variable, some properties - i.e. min, max, numer of columns, ... - are determined and saved in SciSnap!Properties. The access to table elements can be performed by indices or labels in the first row or column - i.e. data(name, 33). Blocks to work with parts of tables are available - i.e. to get subsections. For tables and subsection properties like ranges, mean, covariance or correlations can be calculated. To tables some methods of machine learning can be applied - i.e. regression line calculation, k-means-clustering with different metrics, k-next-neighbours, DBSCAN or ID3 decision tree. You can also perform pooling operations, calculate the entropy, or use convolution kernels i.e. for image operations like edge detection. If the content of a table is numerical, so the table is a matrix, you can use the blocks of the Math-tools.

This category contains blocks to use any sprite or the stage as a sketchpad for plots. In the beginning the properties for the used "pad" are set to standard values, which can be changed by corresponding blocks. Blocks are available for drawing the graphs of any functions as well as for plots of numerical and mixed data or histograms. The scales can be automatically set to "pretty" values. Some examples explain how to use them.

block-definition.s: configure %'sprite' as a PlotPad width: %'width' height: %'height' $nl color: %'color' with close-button? %'withCloseButton?' left? %'left?' size: %'closeButtonSize'
block-definition.comment: Creates a new empty costume of the specified size and color and sets the local properties.

custom-block.l: This category contains blocks for making SQL queries to databases. The default is a server of the University of Goettingen, which provides different databases. First, one of the databases should be selected. Then their tables and, if necessary, attributes can be displayed. It is recommended to display these values permanently as "dialogs" to make it easier to compose SQL queries. SQL queries can be created simple or more complex. The results of the two blocks produce texts. These can be executed using the "exec SQL-command" block. Consequently, SQL statements can also be entered directly there. The usual predicates and operators are available as blocks for generating SQL queries. No changes can be made to the databases.

block-definition.comment: Creates SQL variables and sets some properties.
Establishes connection and sets the corresponding properties. Change parameters if necessary.

custom-block.l: This category contains blocks for using any sprite or the stage as a sketchpad for image display and processing. Initially, the properties for the "pad" used are set to default values, which can be changed using the corresponding blocks. Blocks are available for importing and displaying image data, manipulating values, working with the mouse, affine transformations, etc. The blocks for drawing standard shapes can be found in SciSnap! globals. For working with images that are larger than the sprite, a "window" can be defined for an image. In this window, the image "behind" can then be moved, enlarged/shrunk etc. using the mouse. Some examples explain how to use the blocks.

block-definition.comment: Creates an Infobox about this category.

custom-block.l: This category contains blocks to convert Snap! to SciSnap!, i.e. to create the corresponding variables, to add some new blocks to the standard categories, and to create the new categories as well as the costumes of SciSnap!. Furthermore, there are blocks for configuring and using "SketchPads", e.g. to draw on them or to close them by mouseclick. The SketchPads of the other categories - e.g. the PlotPad, MathPad, ... - are based on this functionality. The category "SciSnap! globals" also contains blocks for reading and writing different file types as well as file or file-list selection with the mouse. Finally, there is a block to display error messages and save them in the SciSnap!Messages variable.

A "window" is an ImagePad, used to display other ImagePads which are switched to the "hide"-modus. The "currrent image" of a window can be scrolled, magnified or shrinked in the background. The part behind the window is displayed in the window using the paste command. Its "instruments" can be used to measure distances or brightness in the window.

custom-block.l: This category contains blocks for using any sprite or the stage as a sketch pad for displaying graphs, i.e. systems made up of vertices ("nodes") and edges. The graphs can be directed or undirected, provided with weights and arranged in a targeted or random manner. Some standard procedures such as depth first or width first search etc. are implemented. The properties of the "pad" used are initially set to default values, which can be changed using the corresponding blocks. Some examples explain how the blocks can be used.

block-definition.s: INFO "NNPad" for dealing with Neural Nets

custom-block.l: INFO about "NNPad for Neural Net operations"

This category contains blocks for using any sprite or the stage as a sketch pad for displaying neural networks. These consist of fully connected layers of perceptrons. The width and depth of the network can be set. The backpropagation method is used as the learning method. The weights in the networks are indicated by coloring of the edges: positive values appear green, negative values red. Values close to zero are shown in gray. These colorings can be used to see how and what a network learns. The properties of the "pad" used are initially set to default values, which can be changed using the corresponding blocks. Some examples explain how the blocks are used.

block-definition.s: configure %'sprite' as a NeuralNetPad width: %'width' height: %'height' $nl color: %'color' with close-button? %'withCloseButton?' left? %'left?' size: %'closeButtonSize'
block-definition.comment: Creates a new empty costume of the specified size and color ans sets local properties for a NeuralNet.

inputs.input: lightGrayblack gray lightGray white red orange yellow green cyan blue magenta

custom-block.s: configure %txt as a SketchPad width: %n height: %n %br color: %s with close-button %b left? %b size: %n

scripts.comment: costume properties: 1: width 2: height 3: back color red 4: back color green 5: back color blue 6: left offset for NN position on stage 7: upper offset for NN position on stage neural net properties: 1: number of layers 2: layer width 3: width of NN 4: height of NN

block-definition.comment: Sets the value of an existing property or inserts it anew.

block-definition.s: INFO "GridPad" for dealing with cellular automata

custom-block.l: This category contains blocks for using any sprite or the stage as a sketch pad for displaying grids that are used for cellular automata, for example. Blocks are available for determining neighborhoods, processing neighboring blocks with settable properties, etc. The colors of the cells are determined via color codes ("numerical values"). The properties of the "pad" used are initially set to default values, which can be changed using the corresponding blocks. Some examples explain how the blocks are used.

block-definition.s: configure %'sprite' as an GridPad width: %'width' height: %'height' $nl color: %'color' with close-button? %'withCloseButton?' left? %'left?' size: %'closeButtonSize'
block-definition.comment: Creates a new empty costume of the specified size and color and sets local properties

inputs.input: lightGrayblack gray lightGray white red orange yellow green cyan blue magenta
